1. Create a string by use of substring starting from 1 to last index and 0th to last but 1 index.
2. Check if the given string s is present in the above created new string and return True if present.

```
class Solution:
    def repeatedSubstringPattern(self, s: str) -> bool:
        combined = "".join( (s[1:], s[:-1]) )
        return s in combined
```

solutions.title: yet-another-linear-o-n-python-solution-with-kmp
solutions.content:
In the previous [post](https://leetcode.com/problems/repeated-substring-pattern/discuss/2425393/Yet-another-Python-solutions-O(n-*-sqrt(n))) I found a solution with complexity O(N * sqrt(N)) which is not in comparison with many other offered solutions with complexity O(N^2). Here I show a difficult but elegant solution by the use of [KMP algorithm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knuth%E2%80%93Morris%E2%80%93Pratt_algorithm). And to be precise, I use only one part of the algorithm ```prefix function()```

Short theory: KMP algorithm finds a pattern in the text in linear time O(N). I encourage everyone to analyze it and remember it by heart because it is used in many applications with strings. The algorithm is so powerful and it takes into account, that while we compare each character of the pattern with the characters in the text, we can reuse partially that information. 
Later I will create a post with details, about how the algorithm works, and post it here.

Examples: 
1) for a string of lenght 9  ```'abcabcabc'```    the prefix function is: [0, 0, 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]
2) for a string of lenght 10 ```'abcabrcabc'``` the prefix function is:  [0, 0, 0, 1, 2, 0, 0, 1, 2, 3]
3) for a string of lenght 10 ```'abcabcabcd'``` the prefix function is: [0, 0, 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 0]

In example 1) the pattern ```'abc'``` is repeated 3 time, in 2) and 3) no patterns
As soon as there are repeated patterns, the prefix functions would increase. And its minimum values is if half of the length of the string because the minimum number of pattern repetitions is 2. The next property: the last element of the ```array s``` is the length of the longest border (when the prefix and the suffix of the string are the same). If we find the difference between the length of the string and the last value of the ```array s``` we find the length of the repeated pattern. And to check if it is a true repeated pattern, the last value of the ```array s``` should be a multiple of the pattern. 
I would recommend to watch lectures [prefix function](https://www.coursera.org/learn/algorithms-on-strings/lecture/exytr/prefix-function) and [compute prefix](https://www.coursera.org/learn/algorithms-on-strings/lecture/5lDsK/computing-prefix-function).

*Please upvote if you like for motivation and karma :)*

```
class Solution:
    def repeatedSubstringPattern(self, p: str) -> bool:
    
        s = [0] * len(p)
        border = 0

        for i in range(1, len(p)):

            while border > 0 and p[i] != p[border]:
                border = s[border - 1]

            if p[border] == p[i]:
                border += 1
            else:
                border = 0

            s[i] = border

        return s[-1] and s[-1] % (len(s) - s[-1]) == 0
```

    public boolean repeatedSubstringPattern(String s) {
        String k =s+s;     // 1.

        if(k.contains(s))    //3.
            return true;

1. Rotation method i.e if we concatenate string with itself it will form a rotation of that string ( "abab" + "abab" -> "abababab"  , "aba"+"aba"->"abaaba"). 
2.  Now remove the first and last letter from the new generated string. It will help to remove the ambigous substring as we need to search for the the original string in this new string. 
3.  Now check for the original string in new string, if it is present then it means the new generated string is the repetition of the substring of original string. ("bababa", from index 1 to 4 we can find the original string therefore returned true)
4.  Whereas in "baab" the original string "aba" is not to be found hence returned false.

solutions.content:
Using KMP, `dfa[i]` helps us find out the length of longest prefix that equals to the suffix in `s[:i]`. aka. if `dfa[i] == d`, then `s[:d] == s[i-d:i]`.
In this case, a valid `s` should be a substring `p` repeated by `k` times (`k >1`). So that `dfa[n-1] == len(p) * (k-1)`. We can check this by `dfa[n-1] != 0 and dfa[n-1] % (n-dfa[n-1]) == 0`. And necessity is easy to prove: if  `dfa[n-1] == len(p) * (k-1)`, `s[:(k-1)p]` == `s[p:]` then s is a `p` repeated by `k` times.
```
def repeatedSubstringPattern(s):
	n = len(s)
	dfa = [0] * n
	d = 0
	for i in range(1, n):
		while d and s[i] != s[d]:
			d = dfa[d-1]
		d += s[i] == s[d]
		dfa[i] = d
	pat = dfa[n-1]
	return pat != 0 and (pat % (n-pat) == 0)
```
Actually running time is much more than `return s in (s+s)[1:-1]` but time complexity is `O(n)`.

solutions.title: one-line-solution
solutions.content:
# Approach 1
Using regular expression with group reference.

# Complexity
- Time complexity: between $$O(n)$$ and $$O(n^2)$$ - depends on implementation of regular expression module.

- Space complexity: between $$O(1)$$ and $$O(n)$$ - depends on implementation of regular expression module.

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def repeatedSubstringPattern(self, s: str) -> bool:
        return re.search(r'^(.+)\1+$', s)
```

# Approach 2
Searching string in cut double string.

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def repeatedSubstringPattern(self, s: str) -> bool:
        return s in (s + s)[1:-1]
```

content.content:
A super problem on strinng matching.
For an interview, I would tell the brute force solution first to interviewer but wont implement it. Then will head to string rotation approach and will implement it.  I have to decide if I should even discuss KMP approach during interview. Maybe someday when I am so confident I would dare to talk the KMP approach. Rabin Karp, though its good to have in the knowlege book I won't use it in interview.

3 good approaches from LC: (Read LC properly before or after reading below notes)
Code: LC
1. **String rotation OR Concatenation** 
This approach will come up to mind if you have done **string rotation problems**.

	**Intution:** (orginal: https://leetcode.com/problems/repeated-substring-pattern/discuss/94344/Simple-Java-solution-2-lines/327797)
If your string S contains a repeating substring, then this means you can "shift and wrap around" your string some number of times and have it match the original string.
Example: abcabc
Shift once: cabcab
Shift twice: bcabca
Shift three times: abcabc
Now the string matches the original string, so you know there is a repeated substring.

	To avoid doing this weird wraparound and using modulo, you can just create a new string SS that is the original string concatenated with itself, and check if this new string contains the original string (shifted some number of times). However, you don't want it to match with the first half (S) and the second half (S), so you remove the first and last characters.

	A similar idea is presented in CTCI problem 1.9, but I think this problem is much more interesting.
	Note: how to get this inution is, when you notice that there should be repetitions of a chunk of chars for a valid answer, doesn't that make you think "since we have repetitions can't we rotate these chunks (or even char by char)  like a cycle?"

2. **Rabin Karp**:


3. **KMP algorithm**:
This approach will come up to mind if you have done string prefix problems. like *strstr*.
**Intuition:**
	* For a substring to build the string if repeated over n times, then the **substring MUST be a prefix** of the string (visualize the logic). This is where we start to move towards MPS thought process.
	* Now we need prefix to be repeated. But you remember that **PREFIX REPEATITION = KMP**. So build a prefix lookup table.
	* If prefix is repeated multiple times in the input string, then the last value in lookup table MUST have a big number (again visualize). To get the correct substring, do n - this value (say l). 
	* Check if any bad characters (non part of repeating substring) had come inside the input string: check if n - l divides n properly. 
The last two points need practise and clear head to come up in an interview
Good explanation and code: https://leetcode.com/problems/repeated-substring-pattern/discuss/94397/C++-O(n)-using-KMP-32ms-8-lines-of-code-with-brief-explanation.

4. **Brute force** : (paru)
	* Get all substrings
	* We don't need all substrings, we need only prefix substrings (visualize logic)
	* For each prefix, check if it matches repeatedly until end of input string. This is O(n * n) (ie, n prefix * n character matching)
	* But we don't need to check for all prefix, we only need prefixes with lengths till half of input string length. Else if repeated, will exceed input string length. O(n/2 * n) = O(n * n)
	* Good observation to discuss to interviewer at last: only if the input string length is a non-prime number, we could have a possible substring that properly divides the input string. An exception would be when all characters are same. So the algo steps would be: check if prime length, if yes check all chars same. If not prime, get all prefix substrings and check individually as mentioned above.

**A note on KMP:**
I think if the candidate knows what problem KMP tries to solve (for a string, at each char is there any prefix matching current suffix, then find the biggest prefix), when to use it (when prefix repetitions happen in a string), how to implement it (using a look up table) and apply this knowledge whenever 
the same problem arises in an interview question, he should get a STRONG HIRE. So it could be expected from a candidate.

I would like to add my experience here.
I was doing LC "Reapeating substring pattern" today. What I understood is, if I could reach upto the point "for a string to be valid in this problem I need any prefix to be repeated till the end of string length without any unwanted characters (ie, not part of repetition) in between repetitions", the "prefix repeatition" could signal me to try out KMP. This only comes from my previous experience of using KMP in Leetcode strstr().

Now once you enter the KMP thought process, you must realize that the last value in the lookup table mus a non 0 and it must be greater than half the input string length (visualize lookup for abcabcabc and abcabc)..
Also visualize the ratio between the last value of loopkup table and the repeated substring length for diff eg like for n=9, 8:1, 7:2, 6:3, etc. Only 1 and 3 divides fully.

Time complexity of kmp strstr: https://qr.ae/pNloVX

Prefix lookup table explanation: https://leetcode.com/problems/shortest-palindrome/discuss/60113/Clean-KMP-solution-with-super-detailed-explanation/827758?page=4&orderBy=newest_to_oldest "Clean KMP solution..." by @myfavcat.

A knowledge point on Pallindrome: The second half of a pallindrome, if **reversed**, forms a repetition of the first half. And "first" half means a prefix of original string. So pallindrome is a variation of prefix repetition. This forms the basis of https://leetcode.com/problems/shortest-palindrome/

2. **Rabin Karp**:


3. **KMP algorithm**:
This approach will come up to mind if you have done string prefix problems. like *strstr*.
**Intuition:**
	* For a substring to build the string if repeated over n times, then the **substring MUST be a prefix** of the string (visualize the logic). This is where we start to move towards MPS thought process.
	* Now we need prefix to be repeated. But you remember that **PREFIX REPEATITION = KMP**. So build a prefix lookup table.
	* If prefix is repeated multiple times in the input string, then the last value in lookup table MUST have a big number (again visualize). To get the correct substring, do n - this value (say l). 
	* Check if any bad characters (non part of repeating substring) had come inside the input string: check if n - l divides n properly. 
The last two points need practise and clear head to come up in an interview
Good explanation and code: https://leetcode.com/problems/repeated-substring-pattern/discuss/94397/C++-O(n)-using-KMP-32ms-8-lines-of-code-with-brief-explanation.

4. **Brute force** : (paru)
	* Get all substrings
	* We don't need all substrings, we need only prefix substrings (visualize logic)
	* For each prefix, check if it matches repeatedly until end of input string. This is O(n * n) (ie, n prefix * n character matching)
	* But we don't need to check for all prefix, we only need prefixes with lengths till half of input string length. Else if repeated, will exceed input string length. O(n/2 * n) = O(n * n)
	* Good observation to discuss to interviewer at last: only if the input string length is a non-prime number, we could have a possible substring that properly divides the input string. An exception would be when all characters are same. So the algo steps would be: check if prime length, if yes check all chars same. If not prime, get all prefix substrings and check individually as mentioned above.

**A note on KMP:**
I think if the candidate knows what problem KMP tries to solve (for a string, at each char is there any prefix matching current suffix, then find the biggest prefix), when to use it (when prefix repetitions happen in a string), how to implement it (using a look up table) and apply this knowledge whenever 
the same problem arises in an interview question, he should get a STRONG HIRE. So it could be expected from a candidate.

3 good approaches from LC: (Read LC properly before or after reading below notes)
Code: LC
1. **String rotation OR Concatenation** 
This approach will come up to mind if you have done **string rotation problems**.

	**Intution:** (orginal: https://leetcode.com/problems/repeated-substring-pattern/discuss/94344/Simple-Java-solution-2-lines/327797)
If your string S contains a repeating substring, then this means you can "shift and wrap around" your string some number of times and have it match the original string.
Example: abcabc
Shift once: cabcab
Shift twice: bcabca
Shift three times: abcabc
Now the string matches the original string, so you know there is a repeated substring.

	To avoid doing this weird wraparound and using modulo, you can just create a new string SS that is the original string concatenated with itself, and check if this new string contains the original string (shifted some number of times). However, you don't want it to match with the first half (S) and the second half (S), so you remove the first and last characters.

	A similar idea is presented in CTCI problem 1.9, but I think this problem is much more interesting.
	Note: how to get this inution is, when you notice that there should be repetitions of a chunk of chars for a valid answer, doesn't that make you think "since we have repetitions can't we rotate these chunks (or even char by char)  like a cycle?"

2. **Rabin Karp**:


3. **KMP algorithm**:
This approach will come up to mind if you have done string prefix problems. like *strstr*.
**Intuition:**
	* For a substring to build the string if repeated over n times, then the **substring MUST be a prefix** of the string (visualize the logic). This is where we start to move towards MPS thought process.
	* Now we need prefix to be repeated. But you remember that **PREFIX REPEATITION = KMP**. So build a prefix lookup table.
	* If prefix is repeated multiple times in the input string, then the last value in lookup table MUST have a big number (again visualize). To get the correct substring, do n - this value (say l). 
	* Check if any bad characters (non part of repeating substring) had come inside the input string: check if n - l divides n properly. 
The last two points need practise and clear head to come up in an interview
Good explanation and code: https://leetcode.com/problems/repeated-substring-pattern/discuss/94397/C++-O(n)-using-KMP-32ms-8-lines-of-code-with-brief-explanation.

4. **Brute force** : (paru)
	* Get all substrings
	* We don't need all substrings, we need only prefix substrings (visualize logic)
	* For each prefix, check if it matches repeatedly until end of input string. This is O(n * n) (ie, n prefix * n character matching)
	* But we don't need to check for all prefix, we only need prefixes with lengths till half of input string length. Else if repeated, will exceed input string length. O(n/2 * n) = O(n * n)
	* Good observation to discuss to interviewer at last: only if the input string length is a non-prime number, we could have a possible substring that properly divides the input string. An exception would be when all characters are same. So the algo steps would be: check if prime length, if yes check all chars same. If not prime, get all prefix substrings and check individually as mentioned above.

**A note on KMP:**
I think if the candidate knows what problem KMP tries to solve (for a string, at each char is there any prefix matching current suffix, then find the biggest prefix), when to use it (when prefix repetitions happen in a string), how to implement it (using a look up table) and apply this knowledge whenever 
the same problem arises in an interview question, he should get a STRONG HIRE. So it could be expected from a candidate.

I would like to add my experience here.
I was doing LC "Reapeating substring pattern" today. What I understood is, if I could reach upto the point "for a string to be valid in this problem I need any prefix to be repeated till the end of string length without any unwanted characters (ie, not part of repetition) in between repetitions", the "prefix repeatition" could signal me to try out KMP. This only comes from my previous experience of using KMP in Leetcode strstr().

Now once you enter the KMP thought process, you must realize that the last value in the lookup table mus a non 0 and it must be greater than half the input string length (visualize lookup for abcabcabc and abcabc)..
Also visualize the ratio between the last value of loopkup table and the repeated substring length for diff eg like for n=9, 8:1, 7:2, 6:3, etc. Only 1 and 3 divides fully.

Time complexity of kmp strstr: https://qr.ae/pNloVX

Prefix lookup table explanation: https://leetcode.com/problems/shortest-palindrome/discuss/60113/Clean-KMP-solution-with-super-detailed-explanation/827758?page=4&orderBy=newest_to_oldest "Clean KMP solution..." by @myfavcat.

So pallindrome is a variation of prefix repetition. This forms the basis of https://leetcode.com/problems/shortest-palindrome/

3 good approaches from LC: (Read LC properly before or after reading below notes)
Code: LC
1. **String rotation OR Concatenation** 
This approach will come up to mind if you have done **string rotation problems**.

	**Intution:** (orginal: https://leetcode.com/problems/repeated-substring-pattern/discuss/94344/Simple-Java-solution-2-lines/327797)
If your string S contains a repeating substring, then this means you can "shift and wrap around" your string some number of times and have it match the original string.
Example: abcabc
Shift once: cabcab
Shift twice: bcabca
Shift three times: abcabc
Now the string matches the original string, so you know there is a repeated substring.

	To avoid doing this weird wraparound and using modulo, you can just create a new string SS that is the original string concatenated with itself, and check if this new string contains the original string (shifted some number of times). However, you don't want it to match with the first half (S) and the second half (S), so you remove the first and last characters.

	A similar idea is presented in CTCI problem 1.9, but I think this problem is much more interesting.
	Note: how to get this inution is, when you notice that there should be repetitions of a chunk of chars for a valid answer, doesn't that make you think "since we have repetitions can't we rotate these chunks (or even char by char)  like a cycle?"

2. **Rabin Karp**:


3. **KMP algorithm**:
This approach will come up to mind if you have done string prefix problems. like *strstr*.
**Intuition:**
	* For a substring to build the string if repeated over n times, then the **substring MUST be a prefix** of the string (visualize the logic). This is where we start to move towards MPS thought process.
	* Now we need prefix to be repeated. But you remember that **PREFIX REPEATITION = KMP**. So build a prefix lookup table.
	* If prefix is repeated multiple times in the input string, then the last value in lookup table MUST have a big number (again visualize). To get the correct substring, do n - this value (say l). 
	* Check if any bad characters (non part of repeating substring) had come inside the input string: check if n - l divides n properly. 
The last two points need practise and clear head to come up in an interview
Good explanation and code: https://leetcode.com/problems/repeated-substring-pattern/discuss/94397/C++-O(n)-using-KMP-32ms-8-lines-of-code-with-brief-explanation.

4. **Brute force** : (paru)
	* Get all substrings
	* We don't need all substrings, we need only prefix substrings (visualize logic)
	* For each prefix, check if it matches repeatedly until end of input string. This is O(n * n) (ie, n prefix * n character matching)
	* But we don't need to check for all prefix, we only need prefixes with lengths till half of input string length. Else if repeated, will exceed input string length. O(n/2 * n) = O(n * n)
	* Good observation to discuss to interviewer at last: only if the input string length is a non-prime number, we could have a possible substring that properly divides the input string. An exception would be when all characters are same. So the algo steps would be: check if prime length, if yes check all chars same. If not prime, get all prefix substrings and check individually as mentioned above.

**A note on KMP:**
I think if the candidate knows what problem KMP tries to solve (for a string, at each char is there any prefix matching current suffix, then find the biggest prefix), when to use it (when prefix repetitions happen in a string), how to implement it (using a look up table) and apply this knowledge whenever 
the same problem arises in an interview question, he should get a STRONG HIRE. So it could be expected from a candidate.

I would like to add my experience here.
I was doing LC "Reapeating substring pattern" today. What I understood is, if I could reach upto the point "for a string to be valid in this problem I need any prefix to be repeated till the end of string length without any unwanted characters (ie, not part of repetition) in between repetitions", the "prefix repeatition" could signal me to try out KMP. This only comes from my previous experience of using KMP in Leetcode strstr().

Now once you enter the KMP thought process, you must realize that the last value in the lookup table mus a non 0 and it must be greater than half the input string length (visualize lookup for abcabcabc and abcabc)..
Also visualize the ratio between the last value of loopkup table and the repeated substring length for diff eg like for n=9, 8:1, 7:2, 6:3, etc. Only 1 and 3 divides fully.

Time complexity of kmp strstr: https://qr.ae/pNloVX

Prefix lookup table explanation: https://leetcode.com/problems/shortest-palindrome/discuss/60113/Clean-KMP-solution-with-super-detailed-explanation/827758?page=4&orderBy=newest_to_oldest "Clean KMP solution..." by @myfavcat.

A knowledge point on Pallindrome: The second half of a pallindrome, if **reversed**, forms a repetition of the first half. And "first" half means a prefix of original string. So pallindrome is a variation of prefix repetition. This forms the basis of https://leetcode.com/problems/shortest-palindrome/

Good explanation and code: https://leetcode.com/problems/repeated-substring-pattern/discuss/94397/C++-O(n)-using-KMP-32ms-8-lines-of-code-with-brief-explanation.

4. **Brute force** : (paru)
	* Get all substrings
	* We don't need all substrings, we need only prefix substrings (visualize logic)
	* For each prefix, check if it matches repeatedly until end of input string. This is O(n * n) (ie, n prefix * n character matching)
	* But we don't need to check for all prefix, we only need prefixes with lengths till half of input string length. Else if repeated, will exceed input string length. O(n/2 * n) = O(n * n)
	* Good observation to discuss to interviewer at last: only if the input string length is a non-prime number, we could have a possible substring that properly divides the input string. An exception would be when all characters are same. So the algo steps would be: check if prime length, if yes check all chars same. If not prime, get all prefix substrings and check individually as mentioned above.

**A note on KMP:**
I think if the candidate knows what problem KMP tries to solve (for a string, at each char is there any prefix matching current suffix, then find the biggest prefix), when to use it (when prefix repetitions happen in a string), how to implement it (using a look up table) and apply this knowledge whenever 
the same problem arises in an interview question, he should get a STRONG HIRE. So it could be expected from a candidate.

3 good approaches from LC: (Read LC properly before or after reading below notes)
Code: LC
1. **String rotation OR Concatenation** 
This approach will come up to mind if you have done **string rotation problems**.

	**Intution:** (orginal: https://leetcode.com/problems/repeated-substring-pattern/discuss/94344/Simple-Java-solution-2-lines/327797)
If your string S contains a repeating substring, then this means you can "shift and wrap around" your string some number of times and have it match the original string.
Example: abcabc
Shift once: cabcab
Shift twice: bcabca
Shift three times: abcabc
Now the string matches the original string, so you know there is a repeated substring.

	To avoid doing this weird wraparound and using modulo, you can just create a new string SS that is the original string concatenated with itself, and check if this new string contains the original string (shifted some number of times). However, you don't want it to match with the first half (S) and the second half (S), so you remove the first and last characters.

	A similar idea is presented in CTCI problem 1.9, but I think this problem is much more interesting.
	Note: how to get this inution is, when you notice that there should be repetitions of a chunk of chars for a valid answer, doesn't that make you think "since we have repetitions can't we rotate these chunks (or even char by char)  like a cycle?"

2. **Rabin Karp**:


3. **KMP algorithm**:
This approach will come up to mind if you have done string prefix problems. like *strstr*.
**Intuition:**
	* For a substring to build the string if repeated over n times, then the **substring MUST be a prefix** of the string (visualize the logic). This is where we start to move towards MPS thought process.
	* Now we need prefix to be repeated. But you remember that **PREFIX REPEATITION = KMP**. So build a prefix lookup table.
	* If prefix is repeated multiple times in the input string, then the last value in lookup table MUST have a big number (again visualize). To get the correct substring, do n - this value (say l). 
	* Check if any bad characters (non part of repeating substring) had come inside the input string: check if n - l divides n properly. 
The last two points need practise and clear head to come up in an interview
Good explanation and code: https://leetcode.com/problems/repeated-substring-pattern/discuss/94397/C++-O(n)-using-KMP-32ms-8-lines-of-code-with-brief-explanation.

An exception would be when all characters are same. So the algo steps would be: check if prime length, if yes check all chars same. 3 good approaches from LC: (Read LC properly before or after reading below notes)
Code: LC
1. **String rotation OR Concatenation** 
This approach will come up to mind if you have done **string rotation problems**.

	**Intution:** (orginal: https://leetcode.com/problems/repeated-substring-pattern/discuss/94344/Simple-Java-solution-2-lines/327797)
If your string S contains a repeating substring, then this means you can "shift and wrap around" your string some number of times and have it match the original string.
Example: abcabc
Shift once: cabcab
Shift twice: bcabca
Shift three times: abcabc
Now the string matches the original string, so you know there is a repeated substring.

	To avoid doing this weird wraparound and using modulo, you can just create a new string SS that is the original string concatenated with itself, and check if this new string contains the original string (shifted some number of times). However, you don't want it to match with the first half (S) and the second half (S), so you remove the first and last characters.

	A similar idea is presented in CTCI problem 1.9, but I think this problem is much more interesting.
	Note: how to get this inution is, when you notice that there should be repetitions of a chunk of chars for a valid answer, doesn't that make you think "since we have repetitions can't we rotate these chunks (or even char by char)  like a cycle?"

2. **Rabin Karp**:


3. **KMP algorithm**:
This approach will come up to mind if you have done string prefix problems. like *strstr*.
**Intuition:**
	* For a substring to build the string if repeated over n times, then the **substring MUST be a prefix** of the string (visualize the logic). This is where we start to move towards MPS thought process.
	* Now we need prefix to be repeated. But you remember that **PREFIX REPEATITION = KMP**. So build a prefix lookup table.
	* If prefix is repeated multiple times in the input string, then the last value in lookup table MUST have a big number (again visualize). To get the correct substring, do n - this value (say l). 
	* Check if any bad characters (non part of repeating substring) had come inside the input string: check if n - l divides n properly. 
The last two points need practise and clear head to come up in an interview
Good explanation and code: https://leetcode.com/problems/repeated-substring-pattern/discuss/94397/C++-O(n)-using-KMP-32ms-8-lines-of-code-with-brief-explanation.

4. **Brute force** : (paru)
	* Get all substrings
	* We don't need all substrings, we need only prefix substrings (visualize logic)
	* For each prefix, check if it matches repeatedly until end of input string. This is O(n * n) (ie, n prefix * n character matching)
	* But we don't need to check for all prefix, we only need prefixes with lengths till half of input string length. Else if repeated, will exceed input string length. O(n/2 * n) = O(n * n)
	* Good observation to discuss to interviewer at last: only if the input string length is a non-prime number, we could have a possible substring that properly divides the input string. An exception would be when all characters are same. So the algo steps would be: check if prime length, if yes check all chars same. If not prime, get all prefix substrings and check individually as mentioned above.

**A note on KMP:**
I think if the candidate knows what problem KMP tries to solve (for a string, at each char is there any prefix matching current suffix, then find the biggest prefix), when to use it (when prefix repetitions happen in a string), how to implement it (using a look up table) and apply this knowledge whenever 
the same problem arises in an interview question, he should get a STRONG HIRE. So it could be expected from a candidate.

I would like to add my experience here.
I was doing LC "Reapeating substring pattern" today. What I understood is, if I could reach upto the point "for a string to be valid in this problem I need any prefix to be repeated till the end of string length without any unwanted characters (ie, not part of repetition) in between repetitions", the "prefix repeatition" could signal me to try out KMP. This only comes from my previous experience of using KMP in Leetcode strstr().

Now once you enter the KMP thought process, you must realize that the last value in the lookup table mus a non 0 and it must be greater than half the input string length (visualize lookup for abcabcabc and abcabc)..
Also visualize the ratio between the last value of loopkup table and the repeated substring length for diff eg like for n=9, 8:1, 7:2, 6:3, etc. Only 1 and 3 divides fully.

Time complexity of kmp strstr: https://qr.ae/pNloVX

Prefix lookup table explanation: https://leetcode.com/problems/shortest-palindrome/discuss/60113/Clean-KMP-solution-with-super-detailed-explanation/827758?page=4&orderBy=newest_to_oldest "Clean KMP solution..." by @myfavcat.

A knowledge point on Pallindrome: The second half of a pallindrome, if **reversed**, forms a repetition of the first half. And "first" half means a prefix of original string. So pallindrome is a variation of prefix repetition. This forms the basis of https://leetcode.com/problems/shortest-palindrome/ 

Write down logic for KMP in strstr later

3 good approaches from LC: (Read LC properly before or after reading below notes)
Code: LC
1. **String rotation OR Concatenation** 
This approach will come up to mind if you have done **string rotation problems**.

	**Intution:** (orginal: https://leetcode.com/problems/repeated-substring-pattern/discuss/94344/Simple-Java-solution-2-lines/327797)
If your string S contains a repeating substring, then this means you can "shift and wrap around" your string some number of times and have it match the original string.
Example: abcabc
Shift once: cabcab
Shift twice: bcabca
Shift three times: abcabc
Now the string matches the original string, so you know there is a repeated substring.

	To avoid doing this weird wraparound and using modulo, you can just create a new string SS that is the original string concatenated with itself, and check if this new string contains the original string (shifted some number of times). However, you don't want it to match with the first half (S) and the second half (S), so you remove the first and last characters.

	A similar idea is presented in CTCI problem 1.9, but I think this problem is much more interesting.
	Note: how to get this inution is, when you notice that there should be repetitions of a chunk of chars for a valid answer, doesn't that make you think "since we have repetitions can't we rotate these chunks (or even char by char)  like a cycle?"

2. **Rabin Karp**:


3. **KMP algorithm**:
This approach will come up to mind if you have done string prefix problems. like *strstr*.
**Intuition:**
	* For a substring to build the string if repeated over n times, then the **substring MUST be a prefix** of the string (visualize the logic). This is where we start to move towards MPS thought process.
	* Now we need prefix to be repeated. But you remember that **PREFIX REPEATITION = KMP**. So build a prefix lookup table.
	* If prefix is repeated multiple times in the input string, then the last value in lookup table MUST have a big number (again visualize). To get the correct substring, do n - this value (say l). 
	* Check if any bad characters (non part of repeating substring) had come inside the input string: check if n - l divides n properly. 
The last two points need practise and clear head to come up in an interview
Good explanation and code: https://leetcode.com/problems/repeated-substring-pattern/discuss/94397/C++-O(n)-using-KMP-32ms-8-lines-of-code-with-brief-explanation.

4. **Brute force** : (paru)
	* Get all substrings
	* We don't need all substrings, we need only prefix substrings (visualize logic)
	* For each prefix, check if it matches repeatedly until end of input string. This is O(n * n) (ie, n prefix * n character matching)
	* But we don't need to check for all prefix, we only need prefixes with lengths till half of input string length. Else if repeated, will exceed input string length. O(n/2 * n) = O(n * n)
	* Good observation to discuss to interviewer at last: only if the input string length is a non-prime number, we could have a possible substring that properly divides the input string. An exception would be when all characters are same. So the algo steps would be: check if prime length, if yes check all chars same. If not prime, get all prefix substrings and check individually as mentioned above.

**A note on KMP:**
I think if the candidate knows what problem KMP tries to solve (for a string, at each char is there any prefix matching current suffix, then find the biggest prefix), when to use it (when prefix repetitions happen in a string), how to implement it (using a look up table) and apply this knowledge whenever 
the same problem arises in an interview question, he should get a STRONG HIRE. So it could be expected from a candidate.

I would like to add my experience here.
I was doing LC "Reapeating substring pattern" today. What I understood is, if I could reach upto the point "for a string to be valid in this problem I need any prefix to be repeated till the end of string length without any unwanted characters (ie, not part of repetition) in between repetitions", the "prefix repeatition" could signal me to try out KMP. This only comes from my previous experience of using KMP in Leetcode strstr().

Now once you enter the KMP thought process, you must realize that the last value in the lookup table mus a non 0 and it must be greater than half the input string length (visualize lookup for abcabcabc and abcabc)..
Also visualize the ratio between the last value of loopkup table and the repeated substring length for diff eg like for n=9, 8:1, 7:2, 6:3, etc. Only 1 and 3 divides fully.

Time complexity of kmp strstr: https://qr.ae/pNloVX

Prefix lookup table explanation: https://leetcode.com/problems/shortest-palindrome/discuss/60113/Clean-KMP-solution-with-super-detailed-explanation/827758?page=4&orderBy=newest_to_oldest "Clean KMP solution..." by @myfavcat.

A knowledge point on Pallindrome: The second half of a pallindrome, if **reversed**, forms a repetition of the first half. And "first" half means a prefix of original string. So pallindrome is a variation of prefix repetition. This forms the basis of https://leetcode.com/problems/shortest-palindrome/

Brute force solution: \nUse a sliding window technique, try every window size of substring then move the window by the substring length.

This problem is easy to solve and hard to optimize:
Here are few condition which can be used to optimize the code:

For **Naive string matching** which involve construction of substring and comparison of those substring the one can reduce his number iteration by:
Here str is the substring of s which can be repeated to form s (possible answer)

1. Check whether it is possible to create n(*an integer*) substring of size =  str.length for which use the condition:
    **if (s.length % str.length == 0)**
2. Before making substring from s check whether the substrings first and last letter are same.

But these all things will optimize the code to much extent but the real optimization would to use better string matching or pattern matching algorithm:
**Robin karp Algorithm**: which involve sort of hashing(*converting the string into number to reduce the comparison time*) and sliding window(* as while applying this approach one would be hashing every window of size str.length)
But the issue with this algo is its time complexity is $$O(mn)$$
which is not good in term of optimization.

**KMP algorithm**: This algo is little bit difficult to code and understand (I write about it this comment would become an article
and no one like to read article)
The best part about this algo is its time complexity is $$O(m + n)$$.

 Next Level Coding: Now, I get it, this isn't a walk in the park. But trust me, the rewards are worth it. It's like leveling up in the coding universe.

If you're thinking about PRIME FACTORS and finding all divisors, STOP!

Keep it Simple.
Just iterate from length `1 ... (N/2)` ( where N is the length of original string ) and check if the current iteration value `i` divides `N` completely i.e. `i % N == 0`, voila you got one of your divisors else continue to next iteration.
Time to check if a substring of this length ( starting at 0 ) is able to partition the entire string correctly or not.
If yes, you got the answer, otherwise continue with next iteration.

But these all things will optimize the code to much extent but the real optimization would to use better string matching or pattern matching algorithm:
**Robin karp Algorithm**: which involve sort of hashing(*converting the string into number to reduce the comparison time*) and sliding window(* as while applying this approach one would be hashing every window of size str.length)
But the issue with this algo is its time complexity is $$O(mn)$$
which is not good in term of optimization.

**KMP algorithm**: This algo is little bit difficult to code and understand (I write about it this comment would become an article
and no one like to read article)
The best part about this algo is its time complexity is $$O(m + n)$$.

title: Maximum Depth of N-ary Tree
question_content:
Given a n-ary tree, find its maximum depth.

The maximum depth is the number of nodes along the longest path from the root node down to the farthest leaf node.

Nary-Tree input serialization is represented in their level order traversal, each group of children is separated by the null value (See examples).

 

Example 1:

Input: root = [1,null,3,2,4,null,5,6]
Output: 3

Example 2:

Input: root = [1,null,2,3,4,5,null,null,6,7,null,8,null,9,10,null,null,11,null,12,null,13,null,null,14]
Output: 5

 

Constraints:

  • The total number of nodes is in the range [0, 104].
  • The depth of the n-ary tree is less than or equal to 1000.

solutions.title: java-bfs-iterative-solution
dfs-bfs-solutions-in-c
python-dfs-solution-with-explanation
solutions.content:
```
"""
# Definition for a Node.
class Node:
    def __init__(self, val, children):
        self.val = val
        self.children = children
"""
class Solution:
    def maxDepth(self, root: 'Node') -> int:
        # Base case
        if root == None:
            return 0
        # Depth level of the tree
        depth = 0
        
        # Loops through children array
        for child in root.children:
            # Compares current depth of depth with a new level of depth 
            # Sets the biggest value to variable depth
            depth = max(depth, self.maxDepth(child))
        
        # As going deeper into the tree increases depth by 1
        print ('root ' + str(root.val) + ' depth ' + str(depth + 1))
        return depth + 1 
    
    # So for the first test case it'll look like
    # first call is the call with root 1
    # depth = 0 -> second call with child 3 -> 
    # it has 2 children so there'll be two calls from for loop
    # call with child 5 -> sets the for loop with child of 5 which is None (Null)
    # this call hits base case and returns 0
    # the same happens with child 6
    # call to child 6 from the for loop -> child of 6 is None -> returns 0
    # depth = max(0, 0) -> depth = 0
    # return to one level higher -> call to child 5 reaches return statement ->
    # depth = 1
    # call to child 6 reaches return statement and it returns 1 ->
    # current depth is 1 because child 5 set it -> max(1, 1) -> depth = 1
    # return to one more level higher
    # call to child 3 reaches return statement ->
    # depth was equal to 1 now it becomes 2 (depth + 1)
    # now it's turn to children 2 and 4 to be called
    # the story is exactly the same as with 5 and 6 only depth is now 2 ->
    # both 2 and 4 return depth 1 that's why it's rejected by max(2, 1)
    # depth remains 2
    # and finally everything returns to the very first call with root 1 
    # it reaches return statement and returns 2+1=3
```

solutions.content:
```python
class Solution1(object):
    def maxDepth(self, root):
        if not root: return 0 #base case 1
        if not root.children: return 1 #base case 2
        heights = [] #hold all the heights of root's children 
        for node in root.children:
            heights.append(self.maxDepth(node))
        return max(heights) + 1


#Simplify solution 1
class Solution2(object):
    def maxDepth(self, root):
        if not root: return 0
        if not root.children: return 1
        height = [self.maxDepth(node) for node in root.children]
        return max(height) + 1


#improve it one more step
class Solution3(object):
    def maxDepth(self, root):
        """
        :type root: Node
        :rtype: int
        """
        if not root: return 0
        if not root.children: return 1
        return max(self.maxDepth(node) for node in root.children) + 1   


#Compare the heights in a loop
class Solution4(object):
    def maxDepth(self, root):
        if not root: return 0
        height = 0
        for node in root.children:
            height = max(self.maxDepth(node), height)
        return height + 1

solutions.title: javascript-3-solutions
python-2-node-n-node-559
solutions.content:
# 104. Maximum Depth of Binary Tree Time: O(N) Proportional to input nodes, Iterates all nodes once. Space: O(H) Maximum nodes within the temporary call stack **Base Case**: 当Node为空的时候，返回高度为0 **Recursive Rule精确版本** : 传递： 左右孩子 向下索取：下一层的左子树和右子树索取**最高深度** 向上返回：选择更高的深度**并且**加上当前层数的高度 (+1) 。最终返回。 **Recursive Rule说人话**: 谁高取谁，并加一 ```python class Solution(object): def maxDepth(self, root): if not root: return 0 left = self.maxDepth(root.left) right= self.maxDepth(root.right) return max(left, right) + 1 ```


# 559. Maximum Depth of N-ary Tree **Base Case**: 当Node为空的时候，返回高度为0 如果需要提前Dereference node.children，那么同时也要给node.children做一个basecase，返回高度1 **Recursive Rule精确版本** : 传递： root.children 向下索取：下一层的所有孩子的**最高深度** 向上返回：选择更高的深度**并且**加上当前层数的高度 (+1) 。最终返回。 **Recursive Rule说人话**: 谁高取谁，并加一 ## 换汤不换药做法 Time: O(N) Proportional to input nodes, Iterates all nodes once. Space: O(H * Tempoaray List Space)) Maximum nodes within the temporary call stack, along with a list initialized on each level of call stack. 换汤不换药做法，利用104的思维，104每层比对左右孩子，那么我们在每一层创建一个临时的List用来保存当前Node的所有子孩子传递上来的高度，取其最大返回 ```python # Readable class Solution(object): def maxDepth(self, root): if not root: return 0 if not root.children: return 1 height = [] for node in root.children: height.append(self.maxDepth(node)) return max(height) + 1 #Pythonic class Solution(object): def maxDepth(self, root): if not root: return 0 if not root.children: return 1 height = [self.maxDepth(node) for node in root.children] return max(height) + 1 ``` ## 利用变量代替每层的Temporary List Time: O(N) Proportional to input nodes, Iterates all nodes once. Space: O(H) Maximum nodes within the temporary call stack 换了点药，其实也一样，就是每层不需要List，用一个变量代替即可。 ```python class Solution(object): def maxDepth(self, root): if not root: return 0 height = 0 for node in root.children: height = max(self.maxDepth(node), height) return height + 1 ```

```python
class Solution(object):
    def maxDepth(self, root):
        if not root: return 0
        left = self.maxDepth(root.left)
        right= self.maxDepth(root.right)
        return max(left, right) + 1
```
```python
# Readable
class Solution(object):
    def maxDepth(self, root):
        if not root: return 0
        if not root.children: return 1
        height = []
        for node in root.children:
            height.append(self.maxDepth(node))
        return max(height) + 1

#Pythonic
class Solution(object):
    def maxDepth(self, root):
        if not root: return 0
        if not root.children: return 1
        height = [self.maxDepth(node) for node in root.children]
        return max(height) + 1
```

    def maxDepth(self, root):
        if not root: return 0
        height = 0
        for node in root.children:
            height = max(self.maxDepth(node), height)
        return height + 1
```

# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
1. Check if the root node is None. If it is, return 0 as the maximum depth since there are no nodes in the tree.
2. Create a variable called max_depth and set it to 0. This variable will keep track of the maximum depth of the tree.
3. Iterate through each child node of the root node.
4. Recursively call the maxDepth function on each child node to get the maximum depth of that subtree.
5. Compare the maximum depth of the current subtree to the current max_depth variable. If the maximum depth is greater than max_depth, set max_depth to the maximum depth of the current subtree.
6. Return max_depth plus 1, since we need to count the root node itself in the depth calculation.

# Complexity

solutions.content:
Python O(n) by DFS

---

**Implementation** by DFS:

```
class Solution:
    def maxDepth(self, root: 'Node') -> int:
        
        if root is None:
            # empty node or empty tree
            return 0
    
        else:
            # DFS to choose the longest path
            
            if root.children:
                # current node has subtrees
                return max( self.maxDepth(child) for child in root.children ) + 1
            
            else:
                # current node is leaf node
                return 1
```

def maxDepth(self, root: 'Node') -> int:
        if not root:
            return 0
        q, MAX = deque(), 1
        q.append((root, 1))
        while q:
            n, l = q.popleft()
            q += [(chi, l + 1) for chi in n.children if (MAX := l + 1)]
        return MAX

using `map` and `flatten`

```ruby
def maxDepth(root, depth = 1)
  return 0 unless root
  children = root.children
  while !children.empty?
    children = children.map(&:children).flatten
    depth += 1
  end
  depth
end
```

solutions.content:
# Approach
1. The function uses a stack to traverse the tree nodes. A stack is a data structure that follows the `Last-In-First-Out` (`LIFO`) principle, meaning the last element added is the first one to be removed.

2. First, it initializes an empty stack.

3. It checks if the `root` node is not None (i.e., it exists). If it does, the root node and its depth (which is initially `1`) are added to the stack as a tuple: `stack += [(root, 1)]`. This sets up the starting point for the tree traversal.

4. It also initializes a variable `maxDepth` to `0`, which will be used to keep track of the `maximum depth` encountered so far.

5. The function enters a `while` loop that continues as long as there are elements in the stack.

6. Inside the loop, it pops the top element from the `stack`, which is a tuple containing a node and its depth: `node, depth = stack.pop()`. This is essentially taking the last added node from the stack to process its depth.

7. It compares the `current depth` with the `maxDepth` variable and updates maxDepth with the maximum value: `maxDepth = max(maxDepth, depth)`. This ensures that maxDepth always stores the `maximum depth` encountered during the traversal.

8. The function then iterates over the `children` of the current node in the loop `for child in node.children:`. For each child, it calculates its depth as `depth + 1` and adds the child and its new depth as a tuple to the stack.

9. The loop continues until all nodes are visited.

10. After the loop, the function returns the calculated `maxDepth`, representing the maximum depth of the tree.

- #### Time Complexity:

1. The time complexity of this DFS algorithm depends on the number of nodes in the tree.
2. In the `worst` case, the algorithm visits all nodes exactly once, as it traverses the entire tree.
3. Therefore, the time complexity is $O(N)$, where `N` is the number of nodes in the tree.

- #### Space Complexity:

1. The space complexity is determined by the stack used for `DFS` traversal.
2. In the `worst` case, the stack can hold all the nodes in the longest path from the root to a leaf. This happens when the tree is `skewed` (essentially forming a linked list).
3. Therefore, the space complexity of the algorithm is $O(H)$, where `H` is the height of the tree. In the worst case (`skewed tree`), `H` can be equal to `N` (`number of nodes`), resulting in a space complexity of $O(N)$.

# Code
```
class Solution(object):
    def maxDepth(self, root):
        stack = []
        if root:
            stack += [(root,1)]
        maxDepth = 0
        while stack:
            node,depth = stack.pop()
            maxDepth = max(maxDepth, depth)
            for child in node.children:
                stack += (child,depth+1),
        return maxDepth

```

solutions.title: bfs-iterative-solution-beats-100-runtime-detailed-explanation
solutions.content:
# Performance
![image.png](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/1faec166-08ed-4304-a46b-67016843af66_1691220098.4566412.png)

# Approach
Here's the explanation:

1. The code starts by creating an empty list named `queue`. This list will be used to perform a `"breadth-first search"` traversal of the tree nodes.

2. Next, there is an `if` statement: `if root:`. It checks if the root node exists (i.e., it's not None). If it exists, the code adds a tuple containing the root `node` and its `depth` (which is initially `1`) to the queue. This tuple represents the current node and its depth in the tree.

3. The code then initializes a variable `maxDepth` to `0`. This variable will be used to keep track of the maximum depth found during the traversal.

4. The code enters a loop using a for loop: `for (node, depth) in queue:`. This loop will iterate over each element `(node, depth)` in the `queue` list.

5. Inside the loop, the code updates the `maxDepth` variable to the `current depth`. This effectively keeps track of the deepest depth found so far.

6. The code then updates the `queue` list with new tuples. It uses a generator expression inside `queue += ...` to add elements to the `queue`. This step is crucial for the breadth-first search traversal. It iterates over each `child node` of the `current node`, and for each child, it creates a new tuple with the child node and its `depth` incremented by `1`. This is how the traversal progresses to deeper levels in the tree.

7. The loop continues until all nodes in the `queue` have been processed. The process of adding child nodes and their depths to the queue continues, effectively exploring the tree in a breadth-first manner.

8. Once the loop ends, the function returns the value of `maxDepth`, which represents the maximum depth of the tree (i.e., the longest path from the root to a leaf node).

In summary, this function performs a `breadth-first search` on a tree structure starting from the root node and finds the `maximum depth` of the tree. The maximum depth is the longest path from the root node to any leaf node.

# Complexity
- #### Time Complexity:

1. Enqueuing the `root` node: $O(1)$
2. The loop iterates through the queue until it becomes empty. In the worst case, it can iterate through all the nodes of the N-ary tree, which results in $O(N)$ iterations.
3. For each node, it iterates through its children to add them to the queue. In the `worst` case, where each node has a large number of children, this step would take $O(M)$ time per node. Since we perform this operation for each node, the total `time complexity` for this step is $O(N * M)$.

So the overall `time complexity` of the function is $O(N * M)$ in the `worst` case.

- #### Space Complexity:

1. The queue is used to store tuples of `(node, depth)`. In the `worst` case, the queue can store all the `nodes` in the tree, which results in a space complexity of $O(N)$.
2. Apart from the queue, the function uses a few variables (e.g., `maxDepth`), but they have constant space usage.

So the overall `space complexity` is $O(N)$ in the `worst` case.

# Code
```
class Solution(object):
    def maxDepth(self, root):
        queue = []
        if root:
            queue += [(root,1)]
        maxDepth = 0
        for (node,depth) in queue:
            maxDepth=depth
            queue += ((child,depth+1) for child in node.children)
        return maxDepth
```

solutions.title: recursive-sollution-o-n-detailed-explanation
solutions.content:
![image.png](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/ebf37284-fa9c-4a2a-9807-df05441c083c_1691216474.9388244.png)

# Approach
Let me explain how it works step by step:

1. First, we check if the tree has a `root` or not. If there is no root (which means the tree is empty), we conclude that the depth of the tree is `0`, because there are no branches or levels.

2. If the tree has a root, we initialize a variable called `depth` to `1`. This means, at least, there is one level (the root level) in the tree.

3. Now, we start exploring the branches of the `root`. We look at each branch one by one.

4. For each branch, we call the `maxDepth` function again. But this time, we pass that branch as the new root. This is like exploring the sub-branches and the sub-branches of sub-branches, until we reach the end of each branch.

5. When we explore each branch, we get a number, and that number tells us how deep that branch goes (the number of levels it has). We add `1` to this number because we are considering the current branch's level as well.

6. We compare this number with the current depth value, which is the maximum depth we have found so far. If the number we got from the current branch is greater than the current depth, we update `depth` to be that number.

7. We repeat this process for each branch. So, we go through all the branches, explore their sub-branches, and keep updating `depth` if we find a deeper branch.

8. Once we finish exploring all the branches, the depth variable will hold the maximum number of levels we found in the entire tree.

9. Finally, we return this `maximum depth` value, which gives us the answer: How deep the tree goes, or in other words, its `maximum depth (height)`.

In summary, the `maxDept`h function explores the tree's branches and sub-branches, recursively finding the `deepest path` possible, and returns the maximum number of levels in the tree, giving us its `height`.

- #### Time complexity:
The time complexity of the code is $$O(N)$$, where `N` is the number of nodes in the tree. This is because, in the worst-case scenario, we may have to visit all nodes of the tree once.

- #### Space complexity:
The space complexity of the code is $$O(H)$$, where `H` is the maximum height (depth) of the tree. This is because the function uses recursion, and the maximum depth of the call stack will be equal to the height of the tree. In other words, the function will create a new call frame for each level of the tree it explores. If the tree is well-balanced (i.e., has a smaller height), the space complexity will be relatively low. However, if the tree is unbalanced (i.e., skewed), the space complexity could be higher.

# Code
```
class Solution(object):
    def maxDepth(self, root):
        if not root:
            return 0
        depth = 1
        for node in root.children:
            curr = self.maxDepth(node)+1
            depth = max(depth, curr)
        return depth
```

"""
# Definition for a Node.
class Node:
    def __init__(self, val=None, children=None):
        self.val = val
        self.children = children
"""

class Solution:
    def maxDepth(self, root: 'Node') -> int:
        if root==None:
            return 0
        que=Deque()
        que.append(root)
        count=0
        while(que):
            n=len(que)
            for _ in range(n):
                cur=que.popleft()
                for i in cur.children:
                    que.append(i)
            count+=1
        return count
```

# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach

- Time complexity:
- O(N)

# Code
```
"""
# Definition for a Node.
class Node:
    def __init__(self, val=None, children=None):
        self.val = val
        self.children = children
"""

class Solution:
    def maxDepth(self, root: 'Node') -> int:
        if root == None:
            return 0
        else:
            depth = 0
            nodes_queue = [root]
            next_nodes_queue = []
            while(nodes_queue):
                node_out = nodes_queue.pop(0)
                for child in node_out.children:
                    next_nodes_queue.append(child)
                if nodes_queue == []:
                    nodes_queue, next_nodes_queue = next_nodes_queue, nodes_queue
                    depth += 1
            return depth
```

[@fantazer](/fantazer) It seems like it's the way your code is written. You are recursively checking the max depth of EVERY NODE first and then using the if condition to set the max variable which is AGAIN recursively searching EVERY NODE.

- Add the depth of the children to a list
- Return the max value of the depths of the children

title: Transpose Matrix
question_content:
Given a 2D integer array matrix, return the transpose of matrix.

The transpose of a matrix is the matrix flipped over its main diagonal, switching the matrix's row and column indices.

 

Example 1:

Input: matrix = [[1,2,3],[4,5,6],[7,8,9]]
Output: [[1,4,7],[2,5,8],[3,6,9]]

Example 2:

Input: matrix = [[1,2,3],[4,5,6]]
Output: [[1,4],[2,5],[3,6]]

 

Constraints:

  • m == matrix.length
  • n == matrix[i].length
  • 1 <= m, n <= 1000
  • 1 <= m * n <= 105
  • -109 <= matrix[i][j] <= 109

solutions.title: c-java-python-easy-understood
python-1-liner
interview-follow-up-square-matrix
c-easiest-w-matrix-creation-filling
python-self-explanatory-1-line-solution
java-solution-with-additional-checks-to-use-in-place-wherever-we-can
python-easy-2-approaches-one-liner
solutions.content:
1. ## **Simple array copy** 
```
class Solution:
    def transpose(self, matrix: List[List[int]]) -> List[List[int]]:
        m,n=len(matrix),len(matrix[0])
        ans = [[None] * m for _ in range(n)]
        for i in range(m):
            for j in range(n):
                ans[j][i]=matrix[i][j]
        
        return ans
```
---


2. ## **One liner using Python Built-in**
```
class Solution:
    def transpose(self, matrix: List[List[int]]) -> List[List[int]]:
        return list(map(list,zip(*matrix))) # we need to explicitly cast as zip returns tuples
```

The tests passes with just doing this even if the return type is wrong:
```
return zip(*matrix)
```

[saja4007](https://leetcode.com/saja4007/) pointed out that `zip` returns tuples instead of list and hence we need to explicitly cast it. Thanks for info [saja4007](https://leetcode.com/saja4007/).

Another one-liner using list comprehension shared by [robbiemu](https://leetcode.com/robbiemu/).

```
class Solution:
    def transpose(self, matrix: List[List[int]]) -> List[List[int]]:
        return [[matrix[y][x] for y in range(len(matrix))] for x in range(len(matrix[0]))]
```

---

**Time - O(number of elements)**
**Space - O(1)** - If you exclude the output array in space calculation.

---

***Please upvote if you find it useful***

solutions.content:
```
var transpose = function(A) {
    return A[0].map((_,  i) => A.map(b => b[i]));
};

```
```
origin_matrix  colIndex        origin_col_arr
   
# 00 01 02                                              00 10 
#           ->  0 1 2  ->  [00, 10][01, 11][02 12] ===  01 11
# 10 11 12                                              02 12
```


Explanation:
The outer map just get every `column index`, it's equal to origin's row length,  e.g: 0 1 2,
then we need transform each such `column index` to a real row, 0 ->  [00, 01],  1 -> [01, 11],  2 -> [02, 12]
Now have col index `i`, and how to get the origin column vertical array?  A.map(row => row[i]) is what we want.

```python
class Solution:
    def transpose(self, A):
        """
        :type A: List[List[int]]
        :rtype: List[List[int]]
        """
        sol = []
        
        for c in range(len(A[0])):
            tmp = []
            for r in range(len(A)):
                tmp.append(A[r][c])
            
            sol.append(tmp)
        
        return sol
```

solutions.content:
def transpose(self, matrix: List[List[int]]) -> List[List[int]]:\
        
        transpose = [] # making an empty list
        
        for col in range(len(matrix[0])):
            transpose.append([]) # Before looping through each column we are append an empty list inside a list. So that we can append each and every value encountered in a particular value to that list.
            
            for row in range(len(matrix)):
                # This is the heart of the code.
                # Here I am appending all the values of a column in the the empty list which we just appended
                transpose[col].append(matrix[row][col])
        return transpose
                
                
# This was the kind of solution which I was looking for. This can be accepted in the interviews. Not the one's which uses zip.

def transpose(self, matrix: List[List[int]]) -> List[List[int]]:\
        
        transpose = [] # making an empty list
        
        for col in range(len(matrix[0])):
            transpose.append([]) # Before looping through each column we are append an empty list inside a list. So that we can append each and every value encountered in a particular value to that list.
            
            for row in range(len(matrix)):
                # This is the heart of the code.
                # Here I am appending all the values of a column in the the empty list which we just appended
                transpose[col].append(matrix[row][col])

# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
O(n^2)
- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def transpose(self, matrix: List[List[int]]) -> List[List[int]]:
        result = [[0 for _ in range(len(matrix))] for _ in range(len(matrix[0]))]
        for i in range(len(matrix)):
            for j in range(len(matrix[0])):
                result[j][i] = matrix[i][j]
        return result

```

solutions.content:
**Simple Two Steps**
1. Iterate over columns.
2. Iterate over rows.

One line solution in python:
```
    def transpose(self, A):
        """
        :type A: List[List[int]]
        :rtype: List[List[int]]
        """
        return [[row[col] for row in A] for col in range(len(A[0]))]
```
And in scala:
```
  def transpose(A: Array[Array[Int]]): Array[Array[Int]] = {
    A(0).indices.map(col => A.map(row => row(col))).toArray
  }
```

solutions.content:
Elixir adds a new wrinkle to this problem given variables in Elixir are immutable. What may be a trivial problem with mutable variables needs a bit more effort to tackle in an immutable world. 
# Approach
1. Flatten `matrix` into a single list and capture it into an anonymous function. 
2. Use a comprehension to count off each new row based on the length of the first row (the count of columns), assigned as `n`.  
3. As we step down the rows in the comprehension, drop the first elements of the flattened `matrix` equivalent to the number of rows already stepped through, counted by `i`, using `Enum.drop/2`. 
4. Use `Enum.take_every/2` to grab the proper values based upon the length of each row, starting with the first item (now exposed by the `Enum.drop/2` function). 

# Solution
Runtime of 393 ms, and memory usage of 50.9 MB. 
```
defmodule Solution do
  @spec transpose(matrix :: [[integer]]) :: [[integer]]
  def transpose(matrix = [row | _]) do
    n = length(row)

    matrix
    |> List.flatten()
    |> (&(for i <- 1..n, do: Enum.take_every(Enum.drop(&1, i - 1), n))).()
  end
end
```

# Testcases
```
[[1,2,3],[4,5,6],[7,8,9]]
[[1,2,3],[4,5,6]]
[[1,2],[4,5]]
[[1,2],[4,5],[7,8]]
```

1. Star mark is used to decompose a list
2. After decomposed, zip them in another direction
3. Voil\xE0! Short and clean transpose!
```python
# Platform: leetcode.com
# No. 867. Transpose Matrix
# Link: https://leetcode.com/problems/transpose-matrix/
# Difficulty: Easy
# Dev: Chumicat
# Date: 2020/11/26
# Submission: https://leetcode.com/submissions/detail/424217618/
# (Time, Space) Complexity : O(mn), O(mn)
class Solution:
    def transpose(self, A: List[List[int]]) -> List[List[int]]:
        return zip(*A)
```

# Intuition
I take one empty array after iterating in every column

# Approach


# Complexity
- Time complexity:
O(m*n)

- Space complexity:
O(n*m)

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def transpose(self, matrix: List[List[int]]) -> List[List[int]]:
        n = len(matrix)
        m = len(matrix[0])
        ans = []

        for i in range(m):
            arr = []
            for j in range(n):
                arr.append(matrix[j][i])
            
            ans.append(arr)
        
        return ans
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
Certainly! Here's the intuition behind the code:

The code aims to transpose a given matrix, which involves flipping its rows and columns. To achieve this, a new matrix `ani` is created with dimensions `[matrix[0].length][matrix.length]`. This new matrix will hold the transposed elements.

The code then iterates over each element in the original matrix using two nested loops. The outer loop iterates over the rows of the matrix, and the inner loop iterates over the columns of each row.

During each iteration, the code accesses the element at index `(i, j)` in the original matrix, where `i` represents the row and `j` represents the column. It assigns this element to the corresponding position `(j, i)` in the `ani` matrix. This swapping of rows and columns effectively transposes the element from the original matrix to the `ani` matrix.

After completing both loops and filling in all elements of `ani`, it holds the transposed matrix. The code then returns the `ani` matrix as the result.

In essence, the code follows a simple approach of iterating over the original matrix and swapping the positions of rows and columns to achieve the transpose operation.

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
The provided code defines a class `Solution` with a method `transpose` that takes a 2D matrix as input and returns its transpose.

Here's the approach taken by the code:

1. Create a new 2D array `ani` with dimensions `[matrix[0].length][matrix.length]`. This will be used to store the transposed matrix.

2. Iterate over the rows of the input matrix using a `for` loop, with the loop variable `i` ranging from 0 to `matrix.length - 1`.

3. Within the outer loop, iterate over the columns of the input matrix using another `for` loop, with the loop variable `j` ranging from 0 to `matrix[i].length - 1`.

4. Access the element at index `(j, i)` in the input matrix, and assign it to the corresponding position `(i, j)` in the `ani` array. This effectively transposes the element from the input matrix to the `ani` array.

5. After both loops have completed, the `ani` array will hold the transposed matrix.

6. Finally, return the `ani` array as the result.

In summary, the code iterates over the elements of the input matrix and assigns them to the corresponding positions in a new array, effectively transposing the matrix.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:  `O(n * m)`
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
The code consists of two nested loops. The outer loop iterates over the rows of the input matrix, and the inner loop iterates over the columns of each row. Since both loops iterate over all elements of the matrix, the time complexity is `O(n * m)`, where n is the number of rows and m is the number of columns in the matrix.

- Space complexity: `O(m * n)`
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
The code uses an additional 2D array ani to store the transposed matrix. The dimensions of this array are `[matrix[0].length][matrix.length]`. Therefore, the space complexity is `O(m * n)`, where m is the number of columns and n is the number of rows in the matrix.

# Code
```
class Solution {
    public int[][] transpose(int[][] matrix) {
        int[][] ani = new int[matrix[0].length][matrix.length];

        for(int i = 0; i<matrix.length;i++){
            for(int j =0; j< matrix[i].length; j++ ){
                ani[j][i] = matrix[i][j];
            }
        }
        return ani;
    }
}

```

solutions.content:
Solution #1 
```
class Solution:
    def transpose(self, matrix: List[List[int]]) -> List[List[int]]:
        n = len (matrix)
        m = len(matrix[0])
        mat = [[0 for i in range (n)] for i in range (m) ]
        for i in range (m):
            for j in range (n):
                mat[i][j] = matrix[j][i]
            
        return mat
```

Solution #2
```
class Solution:
    def transpose(self, matrix: List[List[int]]) -> List[List[int]]:
        m = len(matrix)
        n = len(matrix[0])
        new = []
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                ele = matrix[j][i]
                new.append(ele)
        b = new
        li = [[int(b[m *i+j]) for j in range (m)]for i in range (n)]
        return li
```

Really easy to understand. Upvote if it helped. Thanks

this\'ll work only for m x m matrix

first you need to now what transpose means , than 2nd step create a transpose empty array so that you can store your matrix (normal array) into transpose array its pretty simple

let me  break down here 👇

transpose = column become row and vice versa!
 
so suppose if a (non transpose) 2d matrix initialized like that : int array[] = new int [matrix.length] [matrix[0].length} (its  a normal 2d array which goes rows then column ) (first row then column).

but in transpose you have to create a opposite array like : int[][] ans =new int [matrix[0].length][matrix.length];  (column and row ) (in it you can store or can say transpose your normal array)

than iterate via for loop and fill each  elements form "matrix"to your new transpose "array" which is like 
array [ j ][ i ]  = matrix [ i ][ j ]      

Note : bc you created earlier a transpose array thats why array[ j ] (column) then [ i ] row happend ,and it tranpose.

Please do not use this in an interview hahaha

`var transpose = matrix => matrix[0].map((row, index) => matrix.map(matRow => matRow[index]))`

Won\'t swapping the variables not work?

this\'ll work only for m x m matrix

first you need to now what transpose means , than 2nd step create a transpose empty array so that you can store your matrix (normal array) into transpose array its pretty simple

let me  break down here 👇

transpose = column become row and vice versa!
 
so suppose if a (non transpose) 2d matrix initialized like that : int array[] = new int [matrix.length] [matrix[0].length} (its  a normal 2d array which goes rows then column ) (first row then column).

but in transpose you have to create a opposite array like : int[][] ans =new int [matrix[0].length][matrix.length];  (column and row ) (in it you can store or can say transpose your normal array)

than iterate via for loop and fill each  elements form "matrix"to your new transpose "array" which is like 
array [ j ][ i ]  = matrix [ i ][ j ]      

Note : bc you created earlier a transpose array thats why array[ j ] (column) then [ i ] row happend ,and it tranpose.

Please do not use this in an interview hahaha

`var transpose = matrix => matrix[0].map((row, index) => matrix.map(matRow => matRow[index]))`

Created from a joint effort with [@indigoarthur](https://leetcode.com/indigoarthur/)

I have tried without creating a new array, and instead tried to replace the values, but it is giving me error, but when i tried same thing in my local IDE, its working perfectly fine. Any suggesstion someone might have?
[@Adonis21](/Adonis21) In transpose a 3*2 matrix will become 2*3 matrix so You have to create a new array as per my observation.

[@Adonis21](/Adonis21)  i was thinking about completing this w/o creating a new arr, but faced w/ the same issue :) maybe one of the option could be creation of a new array in if statement, when it\'s not possible to return correct answer with in the same array, and processing the same matrix when it is a square one? but this is just for fun)
Probably you could try this approach  - https://leetcode.com/problems/transpose-matrix/solutions/3172907/transposing-in-place-python-a-funny-solution/
Got it, it would not work for matrixes that are not square matrix. So, is there not any solution without making a new matrix?
[@user8698Xs](/user8698Xs) because matrix does not have same number of rows and column
I also wrote similar code, and caught an error when accessing an array element. The problem does not specify that the matrix has the same number of rows and columns, so this is the problem.
return zip(*A)
`return (zip(*A))`
Won\'t swapping the variables not work?

transpose = column become row and vice versa!
 
so suppose if a (non transpose) 2d matrix initialized like that : int array[] = new int [matrix.length] [matrix[0].length} (its  a normal 2d array which goes rows then column ) (first row then column).

but in transpose you have to create a opposite array like : int[][] ans =new int [matrix[0].length][matrix.length];  (column and row ) (in it you can store or can say transpose your normal array)

than iterate via for loop and fill each  elements form "matrix"to your new transpose "array" which is like 
array [ j ][ i ]  = matrix [ i ][ j ]      

Note : bc you created earlier a transpose array thats why array[ j ] (column) then [ i ] row happend ,and it tranpose.

Please do not use this in an interview hahaha

`var transpose = matrix => matrix[0].map((row, index) => matrix.map(matRow => matRow[index]))`

Created from a joint effort with [@indigoarthur](https://leetcode.com/indigoarthur/)

I have tried without creating a new array, and instead tried to replace the values, but it is giving me error, but when i tried same thing in my local IDE, its working perfectly fine. Any suggesstion someone might have?
[@Adonis21](/Adonis21) In transpose a 3*2 matrix will become 2*3 matrix so You have to create a new array as per my observation.

[@Adonis21](/Adonis21)  i was thinking about completing this w/o creating a new arr, but faced w/ the same issue :) maybe one of the option could be creation of a new array in if statement, when it\'s not possible to return correct answer with in the same array, and processing the same matrix when it is a square one? but this is just for fun)
Probably you could try this approach  - https://leetcode.com/problems/transpose-matrix/solutions/3172907/transposing-in-place-python-a-funny-solution/
Got it, it would not work for matrixes that are not square matrix. So, is there not any solution without making a new matrix?
[@user8698Xs](/user8698Xs) because matrix does not have same number of rows and column
I also wrote similar code, and caught an error when accessing an array element. The problem does not specify that the matrix has the same number of rows and columns, so this is the problem.
return zip(*A)
`return (zip(*A))`
Won\'t swapping the variables not work?
